I am trying to run the following using liquibase

```oracle
--liquibase formatted sql

--changeset id:1
DECLARE str varchar(30);
BEGIN
	str := 'something';
  	update table_name set comment = str where id=1; 
END;
```

But I am getting the following error. How to fix this?

```
[ERROR]      Reason: liquibase.exception.DatabaseException: ORA-06550: line 1, column 23:
[ERROR] PLS-00103: Encountered the symbol "end-of-file" when expecting one of the following:
[ERROR] 
[ERROR]    := ; not null default character
[ERROR]  [Failed SQL: DECLARE str varchar(30)]
```

If I remove ';' after DECLARE and execute I am getting the following error

```[ERROR]      Reason: liquibase.exception.DatabaseException: ORA-06550: line 2, column 1:
[ERROR] PLS-00103: Encountered the symbol "BEGIN" when expecting one of the following:
[ERROR] 
[ERROR]    := ; not null default character
[ERROR] The symbol ";" was substituted for "BEGIN" to continue.
[ERROR] ORA-06550: line 3, column 16:
[ERROR] PLS-00103: Encountered the symbol "end-of-file" when expecting one of the following:
[ERROR] 
[ERROR]    * & = - + ; < / > at in is mod remainder not rem
[ERROR]    <an exponent (**)> <> or != or ~= >= <= <> and or like like2
[ERROR]    like4 likec between || multiset m
[ERROR]  [Failed SQL: DECLARE str varchar(30)
[ERROR] BEGIN
[ERROR] 	str := 'something']
```

EDIT:

From help in comments my issue got fixed by adding "/" at the end
```oracle
--liquibase formatted sql

--changeset id:1
DECLARE str varchar(30);
BEGIN
	str := 'something';
  	update table_name set comment = str where id=1; 
END;
/
```

answers.body_markdown:
If it is an option you could use GZipInputStream/GZipOutputStream to minimize disk I/O.

Files.newBufferedReader/Writer use a default buffer size, 8 KB I believe. You might try a larger buffer.

Converting to String, Unicode, slows down to (and uses twice the memory). The used UTF-8 is not as simple as StandardCharsets.ISO_8859_1.

Best would be if you can work with **bytes** for the most part and only for specific CSV fields convert them to String.

A memory mapped file might be the most appropriate. Parallelism might be used by file ranges, spitting up the file.

    try (FileChannel sourceChannel = new RandomAccessFile("source.csv","r").getChannel(); ...
    MappedByteBuffer buf = sourceChannel.map(...);

This will become a bit much code, getting lines right on `(byte)'\n'`, but not overly complex.

On `scrollViewDidScroll(_:)` get the center point of the screen as `CGpoint`.

Select the item

answers.body_markdown:
There is no way in Git to hide branches from others who have read access to the repository.  Even if you use hidden refs (which are not available in most hosting solutions), it's possible to extract information about other commits.

If you need to store private data, you should use a separate, private repository.  Alternately, if this is only for CI, you can store your data encrypted in the repository and use a secret in the CI system to decrypt it only for CI purposes.  GitHub [describes how to do this](https://help.github.com/en/github/automating-your-workflow-with-github-actions/virtual-environments-for-github-actions#creating-and-using-secrets-encrypted-variables) using `gpg` for GitHub Actions; you can follow similar steps for GitLab.

Probably `string_to_array` will be slightly more efficient than `split_part` here because string splitting will be done only once for each row.

    SELECT

      val_arr[2] AS species
    FROM (
      SELECT string_to_array(val, ' ') as val_arr
      FROM (
        VALUES
          ('aaa bbb'),
          ('cc dddd'),
          ('e fffff')
      ) t (val)
    ) tt;

answers.body_markdown:
The above code works without any additional locking, but it can be simplified to the following idiomatic form

    // If word doesn't exist, create a new atomic integer, otherwise return the existing
    wordCounter.computeIfAbsent(word, k -> new AtomicInteger(0))
        .incrementAndGet();  // increment it

Your code looks a bit like [double checked locking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-checked_locking), in that `putIfAbsent()` is used after the null-check to avoid overwriting a value that was possibly put there by another thread. However that path creates an extra `AtomicInteger` which doesn't happen with DCL. The extra object probably wouldn't matter much, but it does make the solution a little less "pure".

answers.body_markdown:
Let's follow what's going on in your code:

1. The expression `1.0 / (m - 2 * p)` yields 0.2, to which the closest representable `double` value is 0.200000000000000011102230246251565404236316680908203125. Notice how precise it is – to 16 significant decimal digits. It's because, due to `1.0` being a `double` literal, the denominator is promoted to `double`, and the whole calculation is done in double precision, thus yielding a `double` value.

2. The value obtained in the previous step is written to `step`, which has type `float`. So the value has to be rounded to the closest representable value, which happens to be 0.20000000298023223876953125.

So your cited result of 0.200003 is not what you should get. Instead, it should be closer to 0.200000003.

> Is there any suggestion to improve the precision?

Yes. Store the value in a higher-precision variable. E.g., instead of `float step`, use `double step`. In this case the value you've calculated won't be rounded once more, so precision will be higher.

Can you get the exact 0.2 value to work with it in the subsequent calculations? With binary floating-point arithmetic, unfortunately, no. In binary, the number 0.2 is a periodic fraction:

0.2<sub>10</sub> = 0.0̅0̅1̅1̅<sub>2</sub> = 0.0011 0011 0011...<sub>2</sub>

See [Is floating point math broken?](https://stackoverflow.com/q/588004/673852) question and its answers for more details.

If you _really_ need decimal calculations, you should use a library solution, e.g. [Boost's `cpp_dec_float`](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_71_0/libs/multiprecision/doc/html/boost_multiprecision/tut/floats/cpp_dec_float.html). Or, if you need arbitrary-precision calculations, you can use e.g. [`cpp_bin_float`](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_66_0/libs/multiprecision/doc/html/boost_multiprecision/tut/floats/cpp_bin_float.html) from the same library. Note that both variants will be orders of magnitude slower than using bulit-in C++ binary floating-point types.

answers.body_markdown:
The reason 
```
x = Application.WorksheetFunction.Countif(Range("D3:D20"), "*array(i)*")
``` 
won't work is because excel sees everything inside of the quotes as part of the string. So it will literally search for `*array(i)*`. This allows us to search for things like brackets `(` in our sheet without throwing errors that the brackets are part of an incomplete statement. 

To omit this you pass the evaluation of the array outside brackets, which means it is evaluated and passes its solution. Then you concatenate the wildcards you need on both sides using `&` like so:
```
x = Application.WorksheetFunction.Countif(Range("D3:D20"), "*" & array(i) & "*")
```
Note that there are brackets around the `*` but not the array statement. Say `array(i)` is "BOB" this will now search for `"*" & BOB & "*"`, concatenated by `&`: `*BOB*`.

Please note this method works for text strings, but is unreliable for numeric values.

answers.title: Un-nesting a list a certain number of times based on parameter
Un-nesting a list a certain number of times based on parameter

answers.body_markdown:
I don't really get the logic in your code when the `n` is negative, but if I understood the problem correctly, and you simply want to add/remove the brackets around your input list, the following code will do it:
```
def nest(x, n):
    if n > 0:
        for _ in range(n):
            x = [x]
    if n < 0:
        for _ in range(-n):
            x = x[0]    
    return x
```
Examples:
```
print(nest([[["hello"]]], 0))
# [[['hello']]]

print(nest([[["hello"]]], 2))
# [[[[['hello']]]]]

print(nest([[["hello"]]], -2))
# ['hello']
```

---

Note that if you specify `n` greater than the number of brackets, this can produce an unexpected result if the inner element is a string:
```
print(nest([[["hello"]]], -4))
# h
```
Probably, you wouldn't want that, so we need either simply return the inner element in this case, or raise an error:
```
def nest(x, n):
    if n > 0:
        for _ in range(n):
            x = [x]
    if n < 0:
        for _ in range(-n):
            if not isinstance(x, list):
                break  # or raise ValueError('Not enough nested levels to unpack')
            x = x[0]    
    return x

print(nest([[["hello"]]], -4))
# hello
answers.title: Un-nesting a list a certain number of times based on parameter

answers.body_markdown:
I suspect you are using the simulated console in your IDE (Eclipse or something) to test-run your program, right? Is this what happens?

[![Eclipse Console Screenshot][1]][1]

The simple answer is: This doesn't work like a real terminal. While you can just type even if the cursor is in the "wrong" line and the input text will appear in the "correct" line, it doesn't create a perfect illusion of a proper terminal.  

Export your program to a runnable `.jar` file and run it on your systems terminal/console with `java -jar yourProgramName.jar` and you will be happy!

When reading the gawk manual, I stumbled across [the following statement][1] (in the footnotes at the end of the page):

> The ordering will vary among awk implementations, which typically use
> hash tables to store array elements and values.

As I understand this, the array indices (which are strings in the first place) are hashed, and those hashes are used as actual indices.

Now I am concerned about *hash collisions*. I am currently making my first noteworthy awk script which will use arrays which will be indexed by long strings (up to 2048 characters). I am not an expert regarding hashes or cryptography, but I am seeing chances for hash collisions here, and since this "application" is critical, I'll have to prevent this by all means.

Hence the question: Can we turn off array index hashing in awk (specifically, gawk)? I'd happily accept the performance penalty (if any).

  [1]: https://www.gnu.org/software/gawk/manual/html_node/Array-Intro.html#Array-Intro

The most important thing to learn is that putting logic like this into triggers is very rarely a good idea in real life. The overhead of maintaining the summed column usually outweighs the cost of deriving a total on demand.

However, for the sake of your schooling the trigger will look something like this (with the caveat that you haven't posted descriptions and keys for the tables you're using, so the actual statement may be wrong for you):
```
create or replace trigger pass_trigger 
after update of stu_status on student
for each row 
begin
  if :new.stu_status = 'P' then

    update subject s
    set s.total_pass_student = s.total_pass_student + 1
    where s.student_id = :new.student_id ;

  end if;
end;
```

answers.body_markdown:
Your query is way over complicated.  It doesn't need a subquery.  It doesn't need a `left join` (because the `where` turns it into an inner join).  The table aliases are inscrutable (not related to the table names).

I think you can just do:

    update s
        set signupdate = sf.firsttouch
        from signups s join
             signupfix sf
             on s.userid = sf.userid   -- guessing on the `join` criteria
        where exists (select 1
                      from orderreport o
                      where o.userid = s.userid and
                            o.orderdate < s.signupdate
                     );

answers.body_markdown:
In this repository, the static library target names conflict with the shared library target names. CMake does not allow this, as the target names must be *unique*. It looks like these ill-advised changes were pushed to the repository, which broke the PAHO CMake build (see [here](https://github.com/eclipse/paho.mqtt.c/commit/8cc51c78b76a1eabd1df3124b0887ce8b01070ff#diff-95e351a3805a1dafa85bf20b81d086e6)). Since the issue has been raised, one would assume a fix will be pushed soon. 

If you need a quick fix however, it is fairly painless to get this working. You can add the `-static` postfix onto the static library names in the `paho.mqtt.c/src/CMakeLists.txt` file. There are two notable sections in which this change need to happen, just search that file for `PAHO_BUILD_STATIC`:

Near [line 94](https://github.com/eclipse/paho.mqtt.c/blob/9f7f45c76c02abee18766ca64c482ba036d0cb2c/src/CMakeLists.txt#L94) (add `-static` to the library names referenced within the if-statement, in bold below):

<pre>
IF (PAHO_BUILD_STATIC)
    ADD_LIBRARY(paho-mqtt3c<b>-static</b> STATIC $<TARGET_OBJECTS:common_obj> MQTTClient.c)
    ADD_LIBRARY(paho-mqtt3a<b>-static</b> STATIC $<TARGET_OBJECTS:common_obj> MQTTAsync.c)

    TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(paho-mqtt3c<b>-static</b> ${LIBS_SYSTEM})
    TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(paho-mqtt3a<b>-static</b> ${LIBS_SYSTEM})

    INSTALL(TARGETS paho-mqtt3c<b>-static</b> paho-mqtt3a<b>-static</b>
        ARCHIVE DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR})
ENDIF() 
</pre>

Near [line 164](https://github.com/eclipse/paho.mqtt.c/blob/9f7f45c76c02abee18766ca64c482ba036d0cb2c/src/CMakeLists.txt#L164) (add `-static` to the library names referenced within the if-statement, in bold below):

<pre>
    IF (PAHO_BUILD_STATIC)
        ADD_LIBRARY(paho-mqtt3cs<b>-static</b> STATIC $<TARGET_OBJECTS:common_ssl_obj> MQTTClient.c SSLSocket.c)
        ADD_LIBRARY(paho-mqtt3as<b>-static</b> STATIC $<TARGET_OBJECTS:common_ssl_obj> MQTTAsync.c SSLSocket.c)

        TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(paho-mqtt3cs<b>-static</b> ${OPENSSL_LIBRARIES} ${LIBS_SYSTEM})
        TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(paho-mqtt3as<b>-static</b> ${OPENSSL_LIBRARIES} ${LIBS_SYSTEM})
        SET_TARGET_PROPERTIES(
        paho-mqtt3cs<b>-static</b> paho-mqtt3as<b>-static</b> PROPERTIES
        VERSION ${CLIENT_VERSION}
        SOVERSION ${PAHO_VERSION_MAJOR}
        COMPILE_DEFINITIONS "OPENSSL=1")

        INSTALL(TARGETS paho-mqtt3cs<b>-static</b> paho-mqtt3as<b>-static</b>
            ARCHIVE DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR})
    ENDIF()
</pre>
After making the changes, clear your CMake cache (or delete the CMakeCache.txt file in your build folder) and re-run CMake. This should resolve the issue.

answers.body_markdown:
Using NumPy's [boolean array indexing](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/arrays.indexing.html#boolean-array-indexing), you can easily access the desired values. You just need to pay attention, that your `mask` (or segment) is of NumPy's `bool_` type.

Let's see this short code snippet, where I compare the mean obtained from `np.mean` with the one explicitly calculated by the given formula:

```python
import cv2
import numpy as np

# Some artificial image
img = np.uint8(255 * np.tile(np.linspace(1, 0, 400), (400, 1)))
cv2.imshow('img', img)

# Some mask (or segment)
mask = np.zeros((400, 400), np.uint8)
mask[10:390, 10:30] = 255
cv2.imshow('mask', mask)

# Convert mask to bool_ type
mask = np.bool_(mask)

# Calculate mean by NumPy's mean
mean = np.mean(img[mask])
print('mean by np.mean:\n', mean)

# Calculate mean explicitly by given formula
mean = np.sum(img[mask]) / np.count_nonzero(mask)
print('mean by formula:\n', mean)

cv2.waitKey(0)
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
```

Outputs (images omitted here):

```lang-none
mean by np.mean:
 242.05
mean by formula:
 242.05
```

Hope that helps!

answers.body_markdown:
Formulas for rotation of initial point around center point by angle:


     x1 = middle.x + (x - middle.x) * cos(angle) - (y - middle.y) * sin(angle)
     y1 = middle.y + (x - middle.x) * sin(angle) + (y - middle.y) * cos(angle)
(this is affine transform - combination of translation middle to origin, rotation about origin and backward translation)

Don't forget to make cos and sin argument in radians rather than degrees like this:

     cos(angle * M_PI / 180)

items.body_markdown:
We are a small development group that follows gitflow(https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow) with "fast-forward only" merge strategy. Prior to merging, all commits are squashed to the associated Jira issue manually. As a result we have a clean and continuous history of features, user stories, bugfixes and hotfixes that can be easily tracked through Jira. 

As a team we have reached some doubts regarding opening new releases while continuing working in development. One of our release tasks is to clean the possible fixups or rephrase commits, while adding new commits fixing issues our clients are detecting in the release. Once the release is ready, we want to move forward to master while bringing back the changes of the release to development, including all squashed commits, rephrases and bugfixes. Our last release didn't go as expected and we had to manually add each each commit to dev through cherry-picking and squashing to be in sync with master, as it went way far ahead than master and tens of merge conflicts where appearing. 

So, what is the best approach to maintain a clean history even in development when working in the release branch alongside development? Should we clean dev. prior to opening the release? How can we add new bugfixes without breaking our history in dev?
items.title: Recommended way to clean Git history during/before a release, add new commits and bring back changes to dev
